letters.reason: Both pages are written on 'Holland-America Line' stationery. The first page is dated 'Jan 4/62' and addressed to 'Liebe Ulla!', discussing wedding preparations. The second page continues the letter, thanking Ulla for a calendar and signing off from 'Dein Onkel'. The content flows logically from one page to the next.

This single page is dated 'Feb. 21/62', addressed to 'Liebe Ulla!', and written on 'Holland-America Line' stationery, similar to L0001 but from a later date. It appears to be a complete, albeit short, letter. No other pages seem to continue it.

A three-page letter from 'Dale' and 'Eric' to 'Mutti' dated 'Vancouver, Nov. 15/62'. The first page discusses pregnancy, a baby bed, and a new apartment in Banff. The second page continues describing the apartment and asks for Knickerbocker trousers for Eric for Christmas. The third page concludes the letter with a closing from 'Dein Dale' and a postscript from 'Eric'. The content is consistent and flows logically across the three pages.

A three-page letter from 'Wanda' and 'Eric' to 'Mutti' dated 'Banff, Dezember 17, 62'. The first page starts the letter, wishing a merry Christmas and describing the move to Banff. The second page continues the description of setting up the new home. The third page concludes with Christmas wishes and is signed 'Eure Wanda'. The OCR quality is poor, but the date, location, topic (moving to Banff, Christmas), and names are consistent.

A single-page letter to 'Liebe Mutti!' dated 'Banff, Dec. 26/62'. The text is heavily duplicated due to a scanning error, but it appears to be a complete letter thanking the recipient for a Christmas letter. No other pages seem to belong to it.
A complete single-page letter to 'Liebe Ursel!' dated 'Banff, Dec. 26, 62'. The sender thanks Ursel for gifts and describes Christmas in Banff. It is signed 'Dein Dack - Eric'.

These two pages appear to be a Christmas card/letter to 'Liebe Ursel!' from 'Onkel'. The first page has a pre-printed Christmas greeting, a personal note, and mentions 'Andri'. The second page continues mid-sentence, describing a child's behavior (likely Andri's) and ends with a closing from 'Dein Onkel'. The content seems to flow, but the OCR quality is poor, making the connection less certain. The names 'Eric, Jale, Andri und Christopher' on the card are likely the family of the sender.

This page is a Christmas card to 'Liebe Ursel!' with a pre-printed greeting from 'Eric, Jule, Andr√© und Christopher'. The handwritten text is very difficult to read due to poor OCR and seems to be a different, less coherent version of the text on page 561E043B-D8C9-45C3-8B9F-A4D47BF5FA0A. It is treated as a separate, single-page item.
